questions.question: 1. Which of the following oscillations is considered a free oscillation?

explanations.a: Correct. SHM is the natural oscillation without external force or damping.
explanations.b: Not correct. Damped oscillation loses energy over time.
explanations.c: Not correct. Forced oscillation requires external driving force.
explanations.d: Not correct. Critical damping prevents oscillation.

questions.question: 2. In damped oscillations, energy of the system:

explanations.a: Not correct. Energy cannot remain constant due to damping.
explanations.b: Correct. Energy is lost due to friction or resistance.
explanations.c: Not correct. No system can gain energy continuously without external source.
explanations.d: Not correct. Infinite energy is not possible.

questions.question: 3. Which type of damping allows the system to return to equilibrium in the shortest possible time without oscillating?

explanations.a: Not correct. Under damping produces oscillations.
explanations.b: Not correct. Over damping takes longer to reach equilibrium.
explanations.c: Correct. Critical damping achieves fastest return without oscillations.
explanations.d: Not correct. Free oscillation has no damping.

questions.question: 4. In forced oscillation, when the frequency of the driving force matches the natural frequency of the system, the phenomenon is called:

explanations.a: Not correct. Attenuation refers to reduction of amplitude.
explanations.b: Correct. Resonance occurs when driving and natural frequencies match.
explanations.c: Not correct. Critical damping is related to stopping oscillations.
explanations.d: Not correct. Superposition refers to addition of waves.

questions.question: 5. Which graph best represents displacement versus time for a free simple harmonic oscillator?

explanations.a: Not correct. Straight line indicates uniform motion, not oscillation.
explanations.b: Not correct. Exponential decay represents damping.
explanations.c: Correct. SHM is represented by sine or cosine wave.
explanations.d: Not correct. Parabolic is for uniformly accelerated motion.

questions.question: 6. For a damped oscillator, the condition for under-damping is:

explanations.c: Correct. Under-damping occurs when b < 2√(km), allowing oscillations with decaying amplitude.
explanations.d: Incorrect. b = 0 means no damping at all (free oscillation).

questions.question: 7. The displacement of an under-damped oscillator is given by x(t) = Ae^(-γt)cos(ωt + φ). What does γ represent?

explanations.a: Incorrect. Natural angular frequency is ω₀ = √(k/m).
explanations.b: Correct. γ = b/2m is the damping coefficient controlling the rate of amplitude decay.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Spring constant per unit mass is k/m = ω₀².
explanations.d: Incorrect. The driving frequency appears in forced oscillation equations.

questions.question: 8. In forced oscillation, the steady-state amplitude is maximum when:

answers.b: Driving frequency ω equals twice the natural frequency ω₀
answers.c: Driving frequency ω is close to the natural frequency ω₀ (resonance)
answers.d: Damping factor b is very large

explanations.a: Incorrect. Zero driving frequency gives no oscillation.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Double the natural frequency does not produce maximum amplitude.
explanations.c: Correct. Resonance occurs when ω ≈ ω₀, maximising the amplitude.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Large damping suppresses amplitude even at resonance.

questions.question: 9. Which of the following is a real-world example of resonance?

answers.a: A car shock absorber returning smoothly to equilibrium
answers.b: A wineglass shattering when sound at its resonant frequency is played
answers.c: A pendulum clock slowing down over time
answers.d: A spring stretching under constant load

explanations.a: Incorrect. That is an example of critical damping.
explanations.b: Correct. The wineglass resonates at its natural frequency, causing large amplitude vibrations that shatter it.
explanations.c: Incorrect. That is an example of damped oscillation.
explanations.d: Incorrect. That is static deformation, not oscillation.

questions.question: 10. In coupled oscillators, energy exchange occurs because:

answers.b: The two systems are connected allowing transfer of energy between them
answers.d: External periodic force acts on each oscillator independently

explanations.a: Incorrect. No physical system has infinite energy.
explanations.b: Correct. Coupled oscillators are connected such that energy can be transferred back and forth between them.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Both oscillators exchange energy and motion.
explanations.d: Incorrect. External force is not required; coupling enables energy transfer.
